because it signed trade agreements with the US. It may be hard for you to 
see, but America is only one out of 196 countries in the world, all of 
which are major trading partners with China. Yes, the US is a big market, 
but it did not make China prosper, please don't flatter yourself too much.﻿

An eye-opener -- the most interesting evidence has emerged from old 
Japanese government documents and suggests that Japan in effect stole the 
islands from China in 1895 as booty of war. Research of over 40 official 
Meiji period documents unearthed from the Japanese National Archives, 
Diplomatic Records Office, and National Institute for Defense Studies 
Library clearly demonstrates that the Meiji government acknowledged Chinese 
ownership of the islands back in 1885. Why USA back-up Japan and promote 
"China Threat" ?  US voters should know what is going on !
 
Reported by Nicholas Kristof - Senior Reporter with New York Times in Sept. 
2012﻿

A former aid to US President Ronald Reagan is questioning his country's 
foreign policy in the South China Sea, calling on the US to stop provoking 
China. 
Douglas Bandow writes frequently on military non-intervention. He was 
formerly a senior fellow at a conservative American think tank. He believes 
that the US should not take side in conflicting sovereignty claims.
"I don't view this as being primarily an American issue. So I don't see 
this as primarily issue for the US military. But this is primarily issue 
for Beijing and for countries in the region. It is really not US should 
want to get militarily involved, especially in the idea of confrontational 
relationship," Bandow said.﻿

China slowdown hits corporate earnings across the board
by Sofia Pitt, NBR.com   July 24, 2015
China: call it the good, bad and ugly for earnings. The world's 
second-largest economy has become a big topic for investors as a deluge of 
U.S. companies report second-quarter results that have taken a hit from 
China's slowdown.
From software companies to drugmakers to fast food chains, economic 
weakness in China is denting multinational companies—and painting a much 
different story from the Chinese government narrative of 7 percent, 
second-quarter gross domestic product growth.
"China is no longer a locomotive of global growth," Mohamed El-Erian, 
Allianz's chief economic adviser, told CNBC on Thursday.

http://nbr.com/2015/07/24/china-slowdown-hits-corporate-earnings-across-the-board/
